body:
Fused function dispatch currently generates a lot of generic code. In most cases, however, the number of distinct fused types in a function signature will be 1 or 2, so a short if-cascade would likely produce less code and be much faster.

The dispatch code is generated in `make_fused_cpdef()` in `FusedNode.py`. It generates Cython code. This could be optimised for the common case of a few (positional) arguments by dispatching directly based on the argument types, instead of comparing full signatures in a loop at runtime.

Migrated from http://trac.cython.org/ticket/829

comment_data.body:
I suppose this issue is officially closed now, but I'd just like to note that AFAIK, even in the best-case scenarios, running a fused `cpdef` no-op function from CPython still takes several times longer than running a statically typed Cython function, a dynamically typed function Python function, or even an untyped Cython function using dynamic calls to `isinstance()` to type local variables at run time.

In particular, I noted that the first, "`instance_checks`" stage in `.make_fused_cpdef()` that generates a sequence of type name strings for incoming arguments uses quite a bit of list indexing and assignment, which could probably be sped up considerably as a single list comprehension.

That shouldn't be too hard to do I think, but there's also a bunch of conditional branching and conditional code generation for conditional branching IIRC, representing a fair bit of special-casing for specific types and external libraries. It's also already `O(n)` IIRC, so I stopped short of trying to change it for #3366.

In the ideal scenario, I think it may also be possible to just do a nested `if`-cascade, and skip the string-based signature checking, matching, indexing, and lookup entirely by directly calling the appropriate specialization with appropriately typed arguments. This is a workaround that I'm still using in project code for performance-critical fused `cpdef` functions that accept dynamic arguments, even with `O(n)` dispatch.

@will-ca I closed this ticket because there is a major improvement now, but I agree that an if-cascade would likely give even better speedups. Basically, the more we can do at code generation time, the less time needs to be spent at runtime. And an if-cascade is perfect for code generation (and not so great for manual coding).

I'll reopen it, in case you or someone else wants to give it another try.

> Why was this reopened?

Because there's probably still room for improvement.

title: fused function dispatch is slow for Python calls
